Angles

1. Sum of angles in polygons


ID is: 1906 Seed is: 1904

Polygon identification

Study the polygon below and answer the questions that follow:

Answer:
  1. Name the polygon:
  2. What is the sum of the interior angles of this polygon? °°
string
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
The answers to both questions depend on the number of sides of the polygon. Start by counting the sides.
STEP: Identify the polygon by the number of sides
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We name polygons based on how many sides they have. The diagram in this question shows a polygon with 55 sides. This polygon is called a pentagon.

STEP: Determine the sum of the interior angles with the formula 180°(n−2)180°(n−2)
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We can determine the sum of the interior angles of a polygon based on how many sides it has using the formula: 180°(n−2)180°(n−2) where nn is the number of sides. A pentagon has 55 sides, so:

Let n be the number of sides∴n=5Sum of Interior angles of a polygon=180°(n−2)=180°×((5)−2)=180°×(3)Sum of Interior angles of a pentagon=540°Let n be the number of sides∴n=5Sum of Interior angles of a polygon=180°(n−2)=180°×((5)−2)=180°×(3)Sum of Interior angles of a pentagon=540°
NOTE: The angle indicated in the figure is the sum of all the angles, not an individual angle.

The formula we are using actually finds out into how many triangles this polygon is divided. The interior angles of a triangle have a sum of 180°180°. So 180°×3=540°180°×3=540°.

The name of this polygon is pentagon and the sum of the interior angles of a pentagon is 540°540°.

Isosceles triangles

Determine the value of yy, giving a reason for your answer.

Answer: y=y= °° (())
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You are given a triangle with two equal sides. The angles opposite those sides will be equal.

STEP: Apply isosceles triangle reasons
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to know two geometry facts about isosceles triangles:

  1. If two sides of a triangle are equal, then the angles opposite those sides will be equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  2. If two angles in a triangle are equal, then the sides opposite those angles will be equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).

The information on the diagram shows that BC=ACBC=AC. In other words, two sides of the triangle are equal. So, the angles opposite these sides will be equal.

y=70°(∠s opp equal sides)y=70°(∠s opp equal sides)
NOTE: It can be challenging to figure out which of the two reasons to use. In this question we are looking for an angle. So, we use the reason that starts with angles: "∠∠s opp equal sides".

Triangles and parallel lines: find two angles

In the diagram below, JK∥LMJK∥LM. Determine the sizes of xx and yy, giving reasons for your answers.

INSTRUCTION: Often there is more than one correct way to answer a geometry question. You must solve for xx and yy in alphabetical order, and with only one reason each.
Answer: x=x= °°
y=y= °°
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that we have learned so far:

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180° (sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).
  • The sides opposite the equal angles in an isosceles triangle are equal (sides opp equal ∠∠s).
  • Corresponding angles on parallel lines are equal (corresp ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
  • Alternate angles on parallel lines are equal (alt ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
  • Co-interior angles on parallel lines add up to 180° (co-int ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM).
STEP: Determine the size of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Think about the triangle and parallel line reasons that we have learned so far:

  • sum of ∠∠s in ΔΔ
  • ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ
  • ∠∠s opp equal sides
  • sides opp equal ∠∠s
  • corresp ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM
  • alt ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM
  • co-int ∠∠s; JK∥LMJK∥LM

We can see that xx is an exterior angle of the triangle because LMLM is an extension of a side of the triangle.

Interior angles in quadrilaterals

Answer: x=x= °°
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

What number do the interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to?

STEP: Remember that the interior angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°360°
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
The interior angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360°360° (sum of ∠∠s in quad).

The interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to 360°360°. This is because any quadrilateral can always be divided into two triangles. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°180°, so the angles in two triangles add up as follows: 180°180° ++ 180°180° == 360°360°.

NOTE: You do not need to show this proof in your working out. It is just here so that you can see where the fact comes from.
STEP: Apply sum of angles in a quad to determine xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

∴x+261°=360°∴x+261°−261°=360°−261°∴x=99°∴x+261°=360°∴x+261°−261°=360°−261°∴x=99°

What number do the interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to?

STEP: Remember that the interior angles of a quadrilateral add up to 360°360°
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
The interior angles in a quadrilateral add up to 360°360° (sum of ∠∠s in quad).

The interior angles of a quadrilateral always add up to 360°360°. This is because any quadrilateral can always be divided into two triangles. The angles in a triangle add up to 180°180°, so the angles in two triangles add up as follows: 180°180° ++ 180°180° == 360°360°.

NOTE: You do not need to show this proof in your working out. It is just here so that you can see where the fact comes from.

∴x+254°=360°∴x+254°−254°=360°−254°∴x=106°∴x+254°=360°∴x+254°−254°=360°−254°∴x=106°

An Isosceles triangle, is any triangle that has two sides with the same length. The unequal side of an isosceles triangle is usually referred to as the "base". Isosceles triangles also have two congruent base angles. When the 3rd angle is a right angle, it is called a "right isosceles triangle". All the interior angles of any triangle add up to 180°180°.

  • The interior angles of a triangle add up to 180°180° (∠∠ sum in ΔΔ).
  • The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the opposite interior angles (ext ∠∠ of ΔΔ).
  • The angles opposite the equal sides in an isosceles triangle are equal (∠∠s opp equal sides).

Polygon identification

What kind of polygon is shown below?

Answer:

This polygon is a/an

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Polygons are named according to the number of sides that they have.

STEP: Name the polygon
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
A polygon is a closed shape made of straight lines. Closed means that one line follows another line until you get back to where you started.

We name polygons by the number of sides they have.

Number of sides Name
3 triangle
4 quadrilateral
5 pentagon
6 hexagon
7 heptagon
8 octagon
9 nonagon
10 decagon

This polygon has 55 sides, so it is called a pentagon.
